Situation1: The partner seems mildly stressed after a routine workday.
Expectation2: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation2: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Story:
I walk through the door, phone still in hand, headset dangling around my neck. My partner sits on the couch, shoulders slumped, eyes fixed on the muted TV. I can tell he’s had one of those days—nothing catastrophic, just the slow grind of work wearing him down. I want to sit beside him, ask about his day, offer a hug, maybe just listen. That’s what he needs from me, and I want to be there for him.

But my break is almost over. The telemarketing compliance system is ruthless; if I’m even a minute late logging back in, it’ll flag me. Too many flags, and I could lose my job. My supervisor’s already warned me once. I glance at the clock, heart pounding. I can’t be late, but I can’t just walk past him either. He looks up, searching my face for comfort, and I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in. I hover in the doorway, torn, wishing I could split myself in two.
